data: Marble cinerary urn without lid (lost after discovery), on sides simple palmettes and ram protomi.
Regular letters: lunate Ε, Σ, cursive Μ. Φ with an extended upright and Υ at l. 4 with extended slanted bars.
Found c. 1624 in “vinea la Mura”, a vineyard close to the city wall.

Observed by Walther “in Foro Merceri seu Mercati-Lunae, apud Vinc. Maioranam”, in the wall of the Loggia by Carrera, in Museo Biscari by Torremuzza and Kaibel, later by Korhonen in magazzino superiore, Collezione Biscari, formerly sala IX 24.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

Korhonen observes that the name of the deceased could be in the nominative form, but the presence of the attribute suggests that it is dative.
To the sweetest Sosia Elate, Aphrodeisios, her husband.
Alla dolcissima Sosia Elate, Aphrodisios, il marito.

The epitaph presents a less common structure, with the name of the deceased probably in dative and the name of the dedicant in nominative followed by an attribute that qualifies his relationship with the deceased (see Korhonen 2004: 87). To be excluded is the interpretation of the epitaph as two nominatives, the first of the name of the deceased, the latter of the name of the dedicant because of the attribute . The indication of the age of the deceased and the dedication verb is omitted. The gentilicium Sosia testifies that the deceased belonged the gens Sosia; her cognomen  is also attested in an inscription of imperial age from Dikaiarchia-Puteoli (CIL 10.2209). The name of the husband, , is well attested in several inscriptions of South Italy (LGPN 3A: 86).

Facsimile Images

1ΣΟΣΙΑ    ΕΛΑΤΗ
2ΓΛΥΚΥΤΑΤΗ
3ΑΦΡΟΔΕΙΣΙΟΣ
4ΣΥΜΒΙΟΣ

Apparatus criticus

  • Text based on photographs;
  • 1-2: Korhonen observes that the name of the deceased could be in the nominative form, but the presence of the attribute suggests that it is dative.

English translation

To the sweetest Sosia Elate, Aphrodeisios, her husband.

Italian translation

Alla dolcissima Sosia Elate, Aphrodisios, il marito.

commentary

The epitaph presents a less common structure, with the name of the deceased probably in dative and the name of the dedicant in nominative followed by an attribute that qualifies his relationship with the deceased (see Korhonen 2004: 87). To be excluded is the interpretation of the epitaph as two nominatives, the first of the name of the deceased, the latter of the name of the dedicant because of the attribute γλυκυτάτη. The indication of the age of the deceased and the dedication verb is omitted. The gentilicium Sosia testifies that the deceased belonged the gens Sosia; her cognomen Ἐλάτη is also attested in an inscription of imperial age from Dikaiarchia-Puteoli (CIL 10.2209). The name of the husband, Ἀφροδείσιος, is well attested in several inscriptions of South Italy (LGPN 3A: 86).
